The sugar glider's gliding membranes create an aerofoil enabling it to glide 50 meters or more.

item.title: NHB sent an invite in April to me, @andpru and several academics from the global South to weigh in on the future of academic publishing. They would publish it without a paywall. None of us coordinated but when I got the proofs a couple of months later... wow! 2/

item.title: I think the vibe across most editorials is that the traditional academic publishing model is fatally flawed and traditional publishers are extractive, bad for science, scandalous, etc. Pretty bold to read that in the pages of an NPG journal 3/
item.description: I think the vibe across most editorials is that the traditional academic publishing model is fatally flawed and traditional publishers are extractive, bad for science, scandalous, etc. Pretty bold to read that in the pages of an NPG journal 3/

item.title: I made an argument that trad publishers can't deal with a supply shock from an increase in paper submissions due to AI because their peer-reviewing pipeline is already breaking at the seams. It's a bad business model. 4/
item.description: I made an argument that trad publishers can't deal with a supply shock from an increase in paper submissions due to AI because their peer-reviewing pipeline is already breaking at the seams. It's a bad business model. 4/

item.title: FWIW, I think the persistence of peer review+paywall despite obvious flaws is not about aspiration to truth but about exclusivity. Adding up IFs of papers published over the last N years is a rational reaction to lack of domain knowledge (for admins) or time (for academics) 5/
item.description: FWIW, I think the persistence of peer review+paywall despite obvious flaws is not about aspiration to truth but about exclusivity. Adding up IFs of papers published over the last N years is a rational reaction to lack of domain knowledge (for admins) or time (for academics) 5/
item.content:encoded: FWIW, I think the persistence of peer review+paywall despite obvious flaws is not about aspiration to truth but about exclusivity. Adding up IFs of papers published over the last N years is a rational reaction to lack of domain knowledge (for admins) or time (for academics) 5/

item.title: I don't think anybody has cracked that nut yet, and it probably won't be fully resolved until we're in a post-scarcity world where research money is assigned non-competitively. But certain subfields–physics, CS, math–have extracted themselves from standard publishing 6/
item.description: I don't think anybody has cracked that nut yet, and it probably won't be fully resolved until we're in a post-scarcity world where research money is assigned non-competitively. But certain subfields–physics, CS, math–have extracted themselves from standard publishing 6/

item.title: Let's keep trying. Let's experiment with bold new ways of publishing science that are more equitable and allow the fruits of publicly funded research to be reaped by the public itself. I'm super excited by new initiatives spearheaded by @neuromatch in this direction 7/7
